title: Fiorina on immigration: Trump 'did not bring this issue up'
text:
September 22, 2015, 04:36 pm Fiorina on immigration: Trump 'did not bring this issue up' By Mark Hensch 
Carly Fiorina on Tuesday said that rival Donald Trump is not responsible for the heavy focus on illegal immigration in the presidential race. 
“With all due respect to Mr. Trump, he did not bring this issue up,” Fiorina told a crowd at The Citadel in Charleston, S.C., according to The Post and Courier . ADVERTISEMENT “Politicians of both sides talk about it, but nobody does anything about it,” the former Hewlett-Packard CEO added. “We have talked about it for every election for 25 years.”
She blamed government “ineptitude” for the nation’s border security struggles, the newspaper reported. 
Fiorina is surging in the polls following a widely hailed performance during last week’s Republican presidential debate, during which she sparred several times with Trump. 
She is trying to capitalize on the debate momentum with a three-day visit to South Carolina, a crucial early-voting state that has been a focus for many of the Republican contenders. 
During her stop at The Citadel, Fiorina said she opposes President Obama’s push to close the prison camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. 
“I don’t think you fix things that aren’t broken,” Fiorina said. “I don’t think Gitmo is broken, [so we should] keep it open.” 
The Associated Press , meanwhile, reported Tuesday that the businesswoman said she favors a tougher stance with China’s leadership. 
“What happens if you let your teenager do bad stuff over and over again, what do they do? Bad stuff,” Fiorina said, according to AP. 
“Well, it’s true of China and [others],” added Fiorina, also noting Iran's and Russia’s actions abroad. 
Fiorina also said she would cancel Chinese President Xi Jinping’s state visit this week in retaliation for hacking attacks on the United States. 
She would instead meet Xi privately while using “economic leverage, retribution and consequences” for any antagonistic actions by Beijing. 
“The Chinese government is struggling. … The stock market is in free-fall,” she said. “They are dependent on this market continuing to be open to them.” 
Fiorina ranks sixth out of 15 candidates, with 6.3 percent support, in the latest RealClearPolitics average of samplings . 
Trump, meanwhile, leads the race for the Republican presidential nomination, with 28.5 percent support.
